bibl.title: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, November 24, 1941

div1.p: Wood thinks the notebook found at the New York Academy of Medicine may be a disappointment to Hench. She describes how Malloch acquired the notebook.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Wood to Philip Showalter Hench, November 24, 1941

opener.dateline:
1338 19th St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
November 24, 1941

div1.p:
Thank you so much for the reprints of your Hygeia article, and
particularly for the list of corrections to go with the docu-
ment, which must have been a considerable labor to prepare.

As for the notebook, I'm afraid it's going to be a disappoint-
ment to you - it's about 8x13 inches, and has stiff cardboard
covers, so could hardly be the little one Lazear carried in his
pocket. It makes me really livid to think that I didn't read
more of it - I don't know the date of the last entry. As I
believe I told you, I had planned to return and finish it the
next day, and then was prevented by a situation which I could
not help but which I wish I'd walked out on anyway, now.

Dr. Malloch came by the notebook in the following manner - and
he doesn't particularly want the Army Med. Lib. to know about
it, he says: a young Negro medical student who had been work-
ing for or at the Army ML came to him with this notebook, which
he said was Reed's own. He said that they had been cleaning
out the Army Library and this had been tossed out, and that he
had rescued it from a trash can and obtained z permission to
keep it. He offered it to Dr. Malloch for several hundred dol-
lars. After a little dickering and the passage of some time,
Dr. Malloch bought it for $25. Dr. Malloch took Dr. Russel's
(?) word that it wasn't Reed's and lost interest in it pretty
much, to judge from the way he spoke of it. He said it just
contained day to day records of temperatures, urines, etc. and
was probably kept by an orderly or by Neate or somebody else
not very exciting.

I'm sending you the photostats under separate cover in the
morning. I haven't had a minute to see or telephone General
Kean, and am going to continue toiling over the hot typewriter
until at least Dec. 1, so I'm in no hurry to have them back and
you can pour over them at your leisure. I think it may turn
out to be rather an interesting discovery, just in helping to
piece out events as they happened; but it isn't anything that
I can very well use. Aside from my personal satisfaction in
having unearthed something new, I'm also very pleased to be able
to turn it over to you for whatever use you can make of it. I'm
not going to be able to get to New York again until January,
probably, to finish it, so why don't you write Dr. Malloch and
ask him about the final entries?

According to the notebook, incidentally, they found electrozone
fairly effective. They took sewage and dumped electrozone in
it, and after a few hours all the little bacilli etc. lay still.

I'm afraid this is all a disappointment to you if you've been
hoping very hard for the lost pocket size notebook. The
photostats I'm sending, inferior as they are, are at least
life size. I'm terribly interested in the identity of the
handwriting. Do let me know if you can make it out. And
take your time about returning the photostats - I won't need
them back until after the 1st.
